H0.text: Sulfur dioxide (SO₂) is the form in which atmospheric sulfur is found.

H1.text: Formaldehyde is the form in which atmospheric sulfur is found.

H2.text: Sulfuric acid is the form in which atmospheric sulfur is found.

H3.text: Sulfur monoxide is the form in which atmospheric sulfur is found.

A4.text: When sulfur-containing fuels such as coal or oil are burned, sulfur dioxide is the main byproduct.

A5.text: Sulfuric acid is formed naturally by the oxidation of sulfide minerals, such as pyrite.

A6.text: Sulfur monoxide has also been found in the atmosphere of Venus, in Comet Hale–Bopp, in 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko, and in the interstellar medium.

A7.text: When concentrated or condensed, it converts to S2O2 (disulfur dioxide).

A8.text: The S−O bond length is 145.8 pm, shorter than in the monomer.

A9.text: Formaldehyde is an organic compound with the chemical formula CH2O and structure H2C=O.
